title: FTSE 100 hits its lowest level since 'Black Monday'
text:

Tue, Sep 22, 2015, 18:02 BST - UK Markets closed FTSE 100 hits its lowest level since 'Black Monday' By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 3 hours ago 752.20 -110.30 
More than £36bn has been wiped off the value of Britain's biggest companies in four hours of trade 
Britain’s benchmark index has hit its lowest level since “Black Monday” on August 24 in intraday trade. 
More than £36bn has been wiped off the value of Britain’s leading companies, as the FTSE 100 faltered, plunging 2.3pc to 5,966.20 after midday. 
The latest sell off means the blue chip index has now fallen by 16pc since hitting a high of 7,104 in April. 
On Black Monday, the FTSE 100 closed at 5,898.87 as a short-lived plunge in financial markets, fuelled by China’s equity malaise, caused mayhem worldwide. 
Now (NYSE: DNOW - news ) , in a scene reminiscent of the turmoil that hit markets on Black Monday, RSA Insurance is the sole survivor of today's sell-off while mining stocks are the biggest casualties. 
Despite Zurich putting an end to takeover talks with RSA on Monday, broker Canaccord Genuity (Other OTC: CCORF - news ) has reinstated the stock’s “buy” rating, helping it climb 1.5pc. 
* How did Black Monday start? Joshua Mahony, of IG Group (Other OTC: IGGHY - news ) , said: “With the FTSE 100 tumbling over 120 points in two hours this morning, it is becoming clear that there is a distinct possibility of yet another crash in financial markets. 
“The steroids of monetary policy may have brought us to heights previously unseen in global markets, yet as the Fed and BoE begin weaning us off this artificial high, we are coming to find ourselves perilously exposed to another major selloff.” 
Commodity stocks were hit as copper prices hit a two-week low and Credit Suisse issued a bearish note on the sector, downgrading and revising target prices as necessary. 
The bank said it is conditions in mining which remain highly uncertain, and it will remain challenging until “China demand and emerging market currencies find a floor”. 
Amid concerns investors had lost confidence in the beleaguered Glencore (Amsterdam: GX8.AS - news ) following the recent dividend cut and equity placing, the stock plunged 13.5pc. The traiding and mining group fell below £1 for the first time ever in intraday trade to 99.6p. 
Meanwhile, Anglo American (LSE: AAL.L - news ) fell 7.5pc and Antofagasta (Other OTC: ANFGF - news ) slid 6.9pc. 
European bourses have also been hit, led lower by lower copper prices and Volkswagen (Xetra: 766400 - news ) , as it faces an investigation into cheating over emissions tests spread to Asia . 
Mr Mahony said: “The issue here is one of reputation and coming from a rich pool of reputable and reliable German carmakers, this could take the sheen off a previously untouchable industry. 
“Today's sell-off across the German automotive sector has seen competitors such as Audi (Other OTC: AUDVF - news ) , Renault (Swiss: RNO.SW - news ) , Daimler (Xetra: 710000 - news ) and Porsche all suffer major losses today. The question on everyone's mind is, if Volkswagen (Other OTC: VLKAF - news ) is doing it, the likeliness is that they all are.” * VW exec admits ‘we totally screwed up’ as South Korea opens probe The German DAX and the CAC in Paris both fell sharply - down 3.2pc after midday. 
Meanwhile, the opening bell on Wall Street also sent tremors across US equity markets. Despite closing in positive territory on Monday, falling oil and copper prices prompted renewed concerns about the health of the Chinese economy, dragging US stocks into the red. 
Chris Beauchamp, of IG (LSE: IGG.L - news ) , said: “US markets are being sold just as heavily as eurozone indices, as buyers search in vain for reasons to be positive.” 
The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 1.6pc, while the S&P 500 was 1.7pc lower and the Nasdaq (NasdaqGS: NDAQ - news ) slipped 1.8pc.
